chapter.title: Input classes
chapter.para: The rest of this paper is concerned with the form required of the input text file. The input can be divided into eight classes.

section.title: Delimiters
section.para: The characters ( and ) are used as delimiters to impose a syntactic structure on the input.

section.title: White space
section.para: White space comprises sequences of space, tab and newline characters, together with comments (see below). It is not significant to the output (&tdf; notation is completely free-form), and serves only to separate syntactic units. Every identifier, number etc. must be terminated by a white space or a delimiter.

section.title: Comments
section.para: Comments may be inserted in the input at any point. They begin with a # character and run to the end of the line.

section.title: Identifiers
section.para: An identifier consists of any sequence of characters drawn from the following set: upper case letters, lower case letters, decimal digits, underscore (_), dot (.), and tilde (~), which does not begin with a decimal digit. tnc generates names beginning with double tilde (~~) for unnamed objects when in decode mode, so the use of such identifiers is not recommended.

section.title: Numbers
section.para: Numbers can be given in octal (prefixed by 0), decimal, or hexadecimal (prefixed by 0x or 0X). Both upper and lower case letters can be used for hex digits. A number can be preceded by any number of + or - signs.

section.title: Strings
section.para: A string consists of a sequence of characters enclosed in double quotes ("). The following escape sequences are recognised:

listitem.para: \xxx, where xxx consists of three octal digits, represents the character with ASCII code xxx.

section.para: Newlines are not allowed in strings unless they are escaped. For all other escaped characters, \x represents x.

section.title: Blanks
section.para: A single minus character (-) has a special meaning. It may be used to indicate the absence of an optional argument or optional group of arguments.

section.title: Bars
section.para: A single vertical bar (|) has a special meaning. It may be used to indicate the end of a sequence of repeated arguments.
